children.subject: I'd actually argue a solid foundational understanding of 61B is more important than 70. 70 only helps you when proving algorithms but fundamentally, what you're learning is an extension from 61B (for the most part of the class). I'd like to view 170 as 61B material but more mathy and more rigor in proving an algorithm's correctness and design decisions rather than using it as a blackbox 61B teaches you to use.

Again, doing well in the class comes from being able to prove algorithms. The main differentiating factor that prevents this from becoming a 61b part 2 is the fact that you have to prove algorithms that you come up with. Oftentimes in graph algorithms, this comes with noticing certain facts about the graph in question (as in that it's acyclic, a DAG, etc.). Even though 61b could be a big factor in your success in the class, so is the proof exposure you get from 70. I did this class without having done 61b beforehand and I would say that 70 is very very useful

170 doesn't really rely on probability except for a very small section at the end which covers streaming/sketching and randomized algos. The more important part from 70 is the graph theory fundamentals and exposure to proofs. I'm not sure that either math 54 nor cs188 can provide that. It's really not recommended to take 170 without 70 unless you are confident in your math abilities

history.content: I'm a Data Science major and want to take 170 in 2021 spring. I'm wondering if for future semesters 70 will be required as well? Do I  need to take cs70 P/NP just to satisfy this requirement? By the beginning of 2021 spring I will have CS 61B, CS188, math54 and probability class finished. So I'm also wondering if these will be solid for taking 170? Thank you!
history.subject: Will pre-reqs for cs170 be enforced for future semesters(2021 spring) as well?
